history.content:
CS Upper divs are generally harder on average than lower divs, but also have a nicer curve (usually curved to around a B+)

----------

Upper division courses tend towards being more advanced / specialized courses. Oftentimes, this means that the courses are more difficult, and many courses are taken primarily by students self-selecting into the courses (which has a complicated relationship with grade distributions).

I don't think that it's a common experience to take upper-divs and suddenly do much worse in them, especially if they're ones that you're interested in (as opposed to ones that everyone takes).

Note that CS upper-divisions have slightly higher official grading guidelines than lower-divs. I don't know if this is the case for physics.
CS Upper divs are generally harder on average than lower divs, but also have a nicer curve (usually curved to around a B+)

I am a second year double major in CS and physics. Well I'm undeclared yet because I still haven't decided whether to pursue both majors. 

So far I've taken all required lower divs for both majors (4 each), 5 physics upper divs and 0 CS upper divs. I've gotten A/A+s  in all of the lower divs quite easily, but am literally worried about passing some of my physics upper divs. 

I am curious whether or not this is a common phenomena for CS courses as well. Is there a chance/is it likely that this will happen again as I take CS upper divs? Do you guys know anyone who did very well in all lower divs but poorly in upper div courses? If not, I will probably give up on the physics major for the sake of my GPA.

Thank you!
history.subject: Discrepancy between lower div and upper div CS
